TopicTitle: [1.12.X] Tantares - Stockalike Soyuz and MIR [16.1][28.05.2024][{Proton Revamp]

Articles.Content:
Errr, http://www.astronautix.com/craft/zarya.htm

I don't see any mention of guns there. In fact, typing "soyuz zarya gunship" brought me to a very weird forum... which probably doesn't really care about historical accuracies.

Errr, http://www.astronautix.com/craft/zarya.htm

I don't see any mention of guns there. In fact, typing "soyuz zarya gunship" brought me to a very weird forum... which probably doesn't really care about historical accuracies.

Ah, hmmm...

I'm using this book as reference.

Sadly, I don't have it hand at the moment.

Basically a diagram of the "Zarya Soyuz" is given: The position of OM and DM are switched, from the DM extends a small cannon (machine gun?). From the service module, there are what look like some extra engines...?

It was developed (or conceptualized), IIRC, to defend Salyut stations, with the threat of the American Space Shuttle on the horizon.

Edit: Found it!

Edited December 23, 2014 by Beale

Errr, http://www.astronautix.com/craft/zarya.htm

I don't see any mention of guns there. In fact, typing "soyuz zarya gunship" brought me to a very weird forum... which probably doesn't really care about historical accuracies.

You may need a lie-down after hearing this news.

You may have been exposed to the mysterious force called "humour".

Some symptoms may include laughter and the like.

You may need a lie-down after hearing this news.

You may have been exposed to the mysterious force called "humour".

Some symptoms may include laughter and the like.

No no, I am the most boring man you will meet!

Deadly serious!

Found it here.

Maybe I've got the name wrong, but the "Soyuz VI" is what I have known as the Zarya. Conceptual combat spacecraft.

"Above the descent module was a recoilless gun developed by the well known Soviet designer A E Nudelman. It was designed for shooting in a vacuum and defending the military research spacecraft from enemy satellite inspector and interceptor satellites. The gun was aimed by maneuvering the entire spacecraft."

Lots more info on astronautix.

Edit: My "To defend against space shuttle attack" was way off, the concept dates back to the '60s.

Edit 2: The "extra engines" also, turn out to be radially mounted RTGs (Solar panels are easy targets!).

Man, I love this stuff.

Also, more combat spacecraft, there is Soyuz P and Soyuz PPK

*Oh, I've got to discover it. Any good books on this myserious force?*

Anyway, Nudelman? The same guy who made the NS-23, NS-37 and NS-45 cannons for soviet WW2 fighter planes? I thought he was much older... too old to work on weapons in the '60s.

*Oh, I've got to discover it. Any good books on this myserious force?*

Anyway, Nudelman? The same guy who made the NS-23, NS-37 and NS-45 cannons for soviet WW2 fighter planes? I thought he was much older... too old to work on weapons in the '60s.

If I have the right one?

It says he died in 1996, however all I can find of his post 1960 work is of laser eye surgery, eh.

I can only imagine, if astronautix is right, that he designed "space guns" for a bit of fun, or technical exercise, in the '40s or '50s design bureaus.

Edited December 23, 2014 by Beale
Yep. Exactly him. I'll leave now before I offtopic again.

I can agree, the Soyuz OM in particular was due a remake since I re-did the Soyuz DM.

Salyut IVAs are all due a makeover also, since the windows on the new exterior models are quite a bit bigger.

I think I can ask, is potentially an IVA like the Salyut control section is currently, more what you have in mind?

Yeah, I don't know if you've ever seen the inside of a Russian style station module, but they do look closer to the middle Salyut part. The big part at the rear of the station looks the worst to me, partly because it is oriented incorrectly. The "ceiling" of the module should be on one of the sides of the module, and the "floor" should be on the opposite side. If you still don't understand, here is a link to a video tour of the ISS. The Russian segment is towards the end of the video, but it gives you a good look at both the DOS and FGB style modules, as well as the Soyuz OM and ATV.

http://youtu.be/afBm0Dpfj_k
Also, for the next update, could you make a longer pressurized crew module for the FGB? I'm not a fan of having to stack two modules for a crew only TKS.

Yep. Exactly him. I'll leave now before I offtopic again.

Hehe, I like the history banter, but if you insist

On this issue, the Wikipedia lies. There would be difficulties, of course, if you put a usual gun in vacuum. There was a specially developed Nudelmann 23-mm gun modification for Salyut-3 according to most Russian sources.
